outputValidation.content:
{
  "problem_id": "P02",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 1.85,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "3 s.f. based on given masses/percentages"
  },
  "method": "Mass of CaCO3 in the limestone = 5.00 g × 0.840 = 4.20 g. Use the atomic data to get Mr values: Mr(CaCO3)=40.1 + 12.0 + 3×16.0 = 100.1, and Mr(CO2)=12.0 + 2×16.0 = 44.0. Moles of CaCO3: n = m/Mr = 4.20/100.1 = 0.04196 mol. From CaCO3 + 2HCl → CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O, the mole ratio CaCO3:CO2 is 1:1, so n(CO2)=0.04196 mol. Mass of CO2 = n×Mr = 0.04196×44.0 = 1.846 g, which rounds to 1.85 g.",
  "key_equations": [
    "n = m / Mr",
    "m = n × Mr",
    "CaCO3 : CO2 = 1 : 1 (from the balanced equation)"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L33",
    "L34",
    "L14",
    "L24"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Only 4.20 g of CaCO3 is present, and 100.1 g CaCO3 gives 44.0 g CO2, so expected CO2 mass ≈ 4.20×(44.0/100.1) ≈ 1.85 g.",
    "Acid is in excess, so CaCO3 is the limiting reagent, consistent with using only its moles to find CO2."
  ]
}

{
  "problem_id": "P03",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.0702,
    "units": "mol dm-3",
    "precision_note": "3 s.f. (limited by 0.150 mol dm-3 and 23.40 cm3)"
  },
  "method": "Convert NaOH volume to dm3: 23.40 cm3 = 0.02340 dm3. Use c = n/V to find moles of NaOH: n(NaOH)=cV=0.150×0.02340=0.00351 mol. From H2SO4 + 2NaOH → Na2SO4 + 2H2O, 2 mol NaOH neutralize 1 mol H2SO4, so n(H2SO4)=0.00351/2=0.001755 mol. Convert acid volume: 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3, then c(H2SO4)=n/V=0.001755/0.02500=0.0702 mol dm-3.",
  "key_equations": [
    "c = n / V",
    "n = cV",
    "n(H2SO4) = n(NaOH) / 2"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L15",
    "L39",
    "L40",
    "L41"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Acid concentration should be lower than NaOH because twice as many moles of NaOH are needed; 0.0702 is < 0.150.",
    "n(NaOH)=3.51×10^-3 mol, so n(H2SO4)=1.755×10^-3 mol; dividing by 0.025 dm3 gives ~7×10^-2 mol dm-3, consistent."
  ]
}

{
  "problem_id": "P05",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.889,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "3 s.f. based on I=1.50 A and t=30.0 min"
  },
  "method": "Convert time: 30.0 min = 1800 s. Charge passed is current × time: Q = 1.50 × 1800 = 2700 C. Using F = 96,500 C mol-1, the moles of electrons transferred are n(e−) = Q/96,500 = 2700/96,500 = 0.02798 mol e−. From Cu2+ + 2e− → Cu, 2 mol e− deposit 1 mol Cu, so n(Cu)=0.02798/2=0.01399 mol. With Ar(Cu)=63.55, mass deposited m = n×Ar = 0.01399×63.55 = 0.8886 g, which rounds to 0.889 g.",
  "key_equations": [
    "Q = I × t",
    "F = 96,500 C mol-1",
    "n(e−) = Q / 96,500",
    "Cu2+ + 2e− → Cu"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L51",
    "L19",
    "L52",
    "L24"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Doubling current or time would double Q and therefore double the mass deposited; the method uses this proportionality.",
    "n(e−)≈0.028 mol gives n(Cu)≈0.014 mol; multiplying by ~64 g/mol gives just under 1 g, consistent with 0.889 g."
  ]
}

value.summary: All six JSON outputs are consistent with the provided report data and equations, with no fabricated quantities and no contradictions. Each solution uses only the constants/formulae given (e.g., dilution c1V1=c2V2 in L16; mole calculations n=m/Mr in L14; Faraday constant F=96,500 in L19; equilibrium expression in L20) and correctly applies stoichiometry from the stated balanced equations (L34, L40, L52). Numerical results are correct to appropriate significant figures, and Kc is reported as unit,
